Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials.
The tiles were designed for a wide range of topics and styles: Islamic geometric figures, Arabic inscriptions, floral decorations, geometric and linear designs and abstract compositions. The tiles are decorated with gold-leaf.
These tiles are mostly found in the mosques of Damascus and Aleppo and in the palaces in Jerusalem, Nazareth and elsewhere in Palestine.
The majority of the floor mosaics were found scattered inside the mosque of Yusuf ibn Ayyub (also known as the Al-Hakim Al-Tirmidhi Mosque) in Damascus.

The tentacles of cydippid ctenophores are typically fringed with tentilla ("little tentacles"), although a few genera have tentillae that are either absent or not present in all species (or even genera). The name "cydippid tentacle" is most often used for those of the genus Cydippe, which occurs in tropical and subtropical waters. The tentacles can be "whipping" or "flipper-like", the former used by the more common ctenodont ctenophores and the latter by the rarer pyrosoma species.

Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not military missions but rather religious in significance. This would be an important distinction because it would mean that the Chinese, instead of exploiting Tibet’s natural resources, were interested in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition. This was a policy that lasted hundreds of years. The Chinese rulers continued to maintain the position of Dalai Lama as religious leader but they did not attempt to subjugate Tibetan society. They sought the friendship of the Tibetans without demanding complete subjection. This was an excellent marriage of Chinese and Tibetan culture. I have yet to read the entire book, but from what I have, I am impressed by Wang’s and Nyima’s arguments and they have given me a lot to think about.

Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs between consumption and digestion of food. It is comprised of 2 phases: the cephalic response and the gastric phase. In the cephalic phase, food travels down from the mouth through a long tube into the stomach. During this phase the food is mixed with saliva and gastric juices to prepare it for digestion. The gastric phase is the next phase and starts when food reaches the stomach. Here, gastric acid, pancreatic enzyme, and bile salts break down both soluble and insoluble fiber. Fiber that remains undigested passes through the duodenum and enters the next section of digestion which is the intestinal phase. The intestinal phase is where the food is broken down in two different sections. The first section is the small intestine and is shorter compared to the large intestine. Many of these teachers claim that the true Christianity, as found in the Bible alone, has been lost in the West for centuries and is now being revealed to individuals in their own time, by a divine source.
Most individuals claim that they have an ongoing, personal relationship with Jesus. Some of them claim to have seen and interacted with Jesus personally and claim to be apostles of the modern day.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much autonomy or self-sufficiency. In early adolescence, children become assertive, and they develop a sense of their own individuality and identity. By age fifteen, most young persons are on their way and into young adulthood, but this is different for families of color.
African American families face many challenges as the dynamics of the Black family are not easily explained by the culture of Blackness. Many African Americans experience the family disintegration process which has resulted from Black women and men being torn from their families throughout slavery. This process was further impacted after slavery by the Black migration from the south to the north and by post-war suburbanization. For the Black family, the disintegration and migration processes have resulted in families that are less cohesive and more likely to experience high rates of family breakdowns and single parent households. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Gondwana split into the supercontinents Laurasia and Gondwana. The first split, in the southern seas is believed to have happened by 185 Ma..
The breakup may have been caused by the collision of the two supercontinents. It formed the Pacific Ocean, the Arctic Ocean, Antarctica, the Atlantic Ocean, and the Indian Ocean. The other split occurred between India and Africa which formed the Indian Ocean. Finally, the supercontinent Laurasia broke apart giving rise to the Atlantic Ocean and the Arctic Ocean.

Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State of Israel was founded almost 70 years ago. It shares borders with Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Egypt and the Palestinian Territories.
Education
There is a compulsory level of 9 years of schooling after which students attend school according to their own ability. After gaining qualifications at the high school level, students can choose to attend vocational training school.
Language
The state language, Hebrew is also the first language of many Arabs living in Israel. Arabic, English, and Russian are commonly spoken and taught in schools.
The government sponsors Israeli students to study abroad. The government and public educational system are run in a socialist way. In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy and needed to be taken to prevent its forces from supporting the forces of his brother-in-law Henry II. In what is probably the most dramatic assault in all 12th century history, John attacked the city without preparation, but had the better of the French defenders. Though outnumbered 4 to 3, his knights, led by Geoffrey de Charny and supported by Henry's men-at-arms under Geoffrey le Baker defeated the much larger Frenchmen under the command of Philip's nephew and brother-in-law. In April 1204 John forced Philip to abandon a planned invasion of his kingdom and sign a peace treaty at Évreux.

Other historians find incongruity in the proposition that the very place where the vast number of the scholars that influenced the scientific revolution received their education should be the place where a true revolution took place. The German university and its professors had not been transformed into an "academy of science," a place where the students and teachers learned to look at nature objectively, and to apply the deductive method of mathematics to their observations and analyses. If anything, this traditional education, despite its superficial "sciencey" title, still represented the medieval-church-inspired, rationalistic outlook, which, as we have seen repeatedly before, was an obstacle to a truly scientific view of nature. This is certainly true of the university in Frankfurt, where Galileo spent two years as a student, and which had one of the most progressive educational reformers of its time, Christoph Scheibe, as rector from 1566 to 1599. Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. He was forced to flee to Scandinavia after his brother, Yaropolk (who wanted to conquer Kievan Rus), conquered Novgorod in 1002. Vladimir made a deal in 1004 with Yaropolk to split the land between them. Yaropolk took Novgorod and Vladimir took Polotsk (a town in the southwest of modern Belarus); the Polotsk principality remained separate from Kievan Rus. Vladimir is supposed to have taken the crown at Kiev in 1011, after the death of the Kiev ruler and Yaropolk's assassination by Vladimir's troops in 1014. A 2010 study on Jewish ancestry by Atzmon-Ostrer et al. stated "Two major groups were identified by principal component analysis which, when combined, can be roughly referred to as Middle Eastern and European." It should be noted that in order to claim that the two major clusters are European and Middle Eastern the authors had to omit the significant Jewish cluster which is present in the majority of their sample.

The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a large body of water in the south of the region that is separated by the Saale river valley from the rest of the state, while the Thüringer Wald lies in the south of Thuringia.

The Official Name of Thuringia
The Region Thuringia is also known as Thüringen (for example on the map of the official regional symbols of Germany), however, due to the pronunciation of Thuringia, it is often called Thüringen, although the state still goes by Thuringia.
The Capital of Thuringia is Weimar.

Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the HDI from the perspective of data error in the underlying health, education and income data, and data selection of the countries included in the index at different points in time. Some data issues, such as the classification of the poor in rural China, have become more difficult to address with the passing of time.
The HDI was created in 1990 when the United Nations Development Program developed a measure of development for comparing countries and regions worldwide—one that was not GDP-centric. But, like GDP, the HDI is not without its data issues.
What data error exists in the HDI scores and how does it affect the comparisons and rankings of countries? What are the implications of correcting the data error of the HDI? Is one version of the HDI more prone to error than another? Economists Hendrik Wolff, Howard Chong and Maximilian Auffhammer discuss the latest research on addressing data issues

Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian (also known as the 'catalan language' in English) is spoken in the Valencian Community, the region that includes Valencia and its province. Catalan is its own language, with separate dialects from Valencian. Catalans call Valencia 'Valenci', whilst Valencians consider themselves 'Valencians'.
Valencia was the scene of the Valencian Uprising of 1648-1659, in which the Spanish crown defeated Catalan independence-seeking forces and annexed Valencia to the Union of Indies, a Spanish overseas empire. Spanish is used in all official business, government, and media, and most of the residents speak Valencian as their primary language. All these beliefs are core tenets of contemporary science.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment on the extraordinary revolution which had been going forward from the French throne... now begins to comprehend what those principles had been which a sudden & total change from all the ordinary usages of Europe, in every state of government, in the public & personal concerns of mankind, could only take place." Burke was a long-time admirer of the French, and had even learned French from an early age.[10]
In The French Revolution: A History, he explained that it would be impossible to understand the revolution simply in terms of economic conditions in France, without a long view of the history of France, and in a context of contemporary conditions in Europe.

In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska created the publishing house Nova knjižnica. It published the first two books of the series, by Dr. Zdravko Popović and Miroslav Petrovič — the poetry collection Nocima and the novel Blic. Other writers from Serbia and Croatia followed, including the first generation of Yugoslav literary critics, who published books on topics such as literary criticism, literary translations and literary theory. The works included in the series have included several important writers, like Vojislav Novaković, Slavka Kovačić, Milan Filipović, Jovan Jovanović Zmajević, Radisa Selimović and Radića Stanković. The Nova knjižnica series has published numerous award winning novels, poetry anthologies and translations over the years.

The UChicago Arts program joins academic departments and programs in the Division of the Humanities and the College, as well as professional organizations including the Court Theatre, SAIC, and The Smart Museum of Art.
The initiative is a University launch from the "Bridging Interdisciplines" Project, a research cluster launched in 2011. UChicago Arts is now a cross-disciplinary, peer-reviewed program in the College in the Committee on Research, chaired by Dean of Research Robert M. Goldwin.
The Arts Program and the College's Department of English are both co-chairs of the Arts in Public Spaces initiative.
